docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''A Big Maintenance Problem at the H.M.O.'' says H.M.O.'s are being penny-wise and pound-foolish in not paying for health behavior interventions and screening tests for early disease detection. Although it may be true that these treatments and tests would decrease costs for the population over the long term, they are not likely to pay off for an H.M.O. This is because people are constantly moving into and out of any given H.M.O. Intervening to prevent future disease in a healthy 30-year-old is not going to pay off if the 30-year-old leaves the H.M.O. before he's likely to get sick.
docs.abstract: Dr James D Sullivan letter on Mar 14 article holds health mainteance organizations lack financial incentive to invest in maintaining health

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: H.M.O.'s must do more to maintain health rather than simply cure disease (''A Big Maintenance Problem at the H.M.O,'' March 14). But one technique not mentioned was differential rates. Smokers should be made to pay more; not as a punishment or a ''sin tax,'' but simply because their unhealthy behavior drives up health care costs. Charging smokers and nonsmokers the same unfairly (and perhaps illegally) forces the great majority, who are nonsmokers, to subsidize those who smoke. Charging smokers more (e.g., an extra $5 per visit) also provides an added strong incentive, and an additional reminder every time they see a health provider, to quit.
docs.abstract: Prof John F Banzhaf letter on Mar 14 article urges health maintenance organization be allowed to charge smokers higher rates

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Boeing Company's white-collar workers returned to work after a 40-day strike, union leaders there declared victory yesterday and national union officials said they hoped to capitalize on it. Leaders of several unions predicted that white-collar workers would take a new, more appreciative look at unions as a result of the impressive gains made by the more than 15,000 Boeing workers in what labor historians are calling the biggest white-collar strike in history.

headline.main: Unions Predict Gain From Boeing Strike

docs.abstract: Union leaders declare victory as Boeing Company's white-collar engineers return to work after 40-day strike; national union officials said they hoped to capitalize on it; several predict white-collar workers will take new, more appreciative look at unions as result of impressive gains made by more than 15,000 Boeing workers in what labor historians say was biggest white-collar strike in history; even some business executives acknowledge white-collar workers, many of whom have long viewed unions as unnecessary, may show new interest in unionizing because Boeing workers did so well in strike; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Boeing engineers and technical workers approved a new contract today, ending one of the biggest white-collar walkouts in the country's history. Members of the union, the Society of Professional Engineering Employees in Aerospace, planned to return to work at 9 a.m. Monday.

headline.main: Engineers End Boeing Strike By Accepting New Contract

docs.lead_paragraph: On a tour of low-income housing here, Leon N. Weiner, a prominent developer, turned to the senior senator from Delaware, William V. Roth Jr., and raised an increasingly familiar question. ''People ask me, 'Is Senator Roth, at his age, ready to make another six-year commitment?' '' Mr. Weiner, who will turn 80 in May, said.

headline.main: A Senior Statesman Is Facing the Threat of Youth

docs.abstract: Republican US Sen William V Roth Jr is campaigning for sixth term to Senate from Delaware at age 79 and faces stiff challenge from state's popular Democratic governor, Thomas R Carper, who is 53; he has become most vulnerable Republican senator in campaign 2000; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With the long march to November under way, Gov. George W. Bush is arguing that his record in Texas proves he is best suited to bring reform to Washington. He has even coined a campaign slogan: ''A Reformer With Results.'' Without question, Mr. Bush has been a popular governor, yet he is not widely viewed in Texas as a reformer.

headline.main: Bush Calls Himself Reformer; the Record Shows the Label May Be a Stretch

docs.abstract: Republican presidential candidate Gov George W Bush, who is popular governor, is not widely viewed by constituents as reformer even though he argues that his record as state's chief executive proves he is best suited to bring reform to Washington; unlike former rival Sen John McCain, who bucked party on variety of issues, Bush is not as confrontational, nor is he usually identified with sweeping change; his record is largely built on compromise and ability to build coalitions with conservative Democrats; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is 12:30 p.m. and I am riding the stationary bicycle at the LivingWell health club, a moderately priced gym a stone's throw from Parliament, in London's (smaller, dinkier) approximation of Capitol Hill. This is prime time for exercise, when urbanites everywhere spend their lunch hours crunching and toning to look as lean and hungry as urbanites everywhere are supposed to look. But not at this gym. On the treadmill next to me is a man in an old gray T-shirt with his stomach hanging down over his too-tight shorts and a face so red and sweaty that he looks like he might well not survive into the evening. Over at the free weights is a woman, wobbly in a retro-style leotard, whose concept of ''reps'' is to heave one of the weights over her head, let gravity pull it back to the ground and then rest for a while.

headline.main: CORRESPONDENCE/No Sweat, Please. They're British.; A Three-Letter Word for a Place Where Londoners Do Heavy Lifting

docs.abstract: Sarah Lyall article notes that on her recent visit to London health club, she noticed that most members were out of shape and proud of it; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S not often that 150 20-somethings get together to watch a dirty movie -- at least, not one that involves a cast of 60-somethings. But that was what was happening on Thursday night at the premiere of ''The Lifestyle,'' a new documentary about swingers in the suburbs that opened at the Pioneer Theater in the East Village. The film, which has been well received, follows the exploits of what Stephen Holden, a critic for The New York Times, called ''gray-haired, potbellied, cellulite-jiggling, over-60 orgiasts.''

headline.main: A NIGHT OUT WITH: David Schisgall; Sex on the Other Side of the Hill

docs.abstract: David Schisgall, director of new documentary about over-60 swingers in suburbs, The Lifestyle, attends premiere and post-screening celebration at restaurant in lower Manhattan; photo (A Night Out With column) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MOST baby boomers could probably use the help of a financial planner as they approach retirement age. But they are often more interested in spending money today than putting it aside for tomorrow, three Westchester planners say. ''You only have to look at the mega houses and SUV's they're buying,'' Anthony Princisvalle, a certified public accountant in Pleasantville with an office in Manhattan, said of the many high wage earners among the baby boom generation.
docs.abstract: Interview with Lawrence J DeNoia, Peeksville, NY, financial planner who says baby boomers should be thinking about retirement plans; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boeing Company said it needed to hold the line on costs, while its engineers union said the giant manufacturer was like a bully going after ''the little kid in the corner with the glasses.'' But the kid had been ''taking kung-fu,'' said the union's director, and the result was one of the largest strikes ever by white-collar workers against a private company. On Friday, after five and a half weeks of picketing had contributed to serious delays in jet deliveries, Boeing and the union reached a tentative pact calling for average 8 percent raises, cash bonuses and the company's withdrawal of a demand for new health-insurance payments.
